speaker: Speaker_F
text: OK , so , um , what I started looking at , uh , to begin with is just uh , content management systems uh , i i in general . So

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , uh what 's uh Sort of the state of the art there is to um uh you have a bunch of of uh documents or learning units or learning objects ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , and you store meta - data uh , associate to them . So there 's some international standards like the I - triple - E , uh There 's an I - triple - E , LON standard ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: and um , these fields are pretty straightforward , you have uh author information , you have uh , size information , format information and so on .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: Uh , but they 're two uh fields that are um , more interesting . One is uh you store keywords associated with the uh with the document , and one is uh , you have sort of a , um ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: well , what is the document about ? So it 's some sort of taxonomic

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , ordering of of the of the units . Now ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: if you sort of put on your

speaker: Speaker_F
text: semantic glasses ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh you say , well that 's not all that easy , because there 's an implicit um , uh , assumption behind that is that uh , all the users of this system share the same interpretation of the keyword and the same interpretation of

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , whichever taxonomy is used , and uh ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: I think that 's a that 's a very that 's a key point of these systems and they sort of always

speaker: Speaker_F
text: brush over this real quickly without

speaker: Speaker_F
text: really elaborating much of that and uh As a matter of fact , the only thing that m apparently really works out so far are library ordering codes , which are very , very coarse grain , so you have some like ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: science , biology , and then But that 's really all that we have at the moment . So I think there 's a huge ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , uh need for improvement there .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: Um , so what I 'm what I try to do is um ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: to have um , uh So . So the scenario is the following , you you 're working on some sort of project and you encounter a certain problem . Now ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: what what we have at our university quite a bit is that uh , students um , try to u

speaker: Speaker_F
text: program a certain assignment , for example , they always run into the same

speaker: Speaker_F
text: problems ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , and they always come running to us , and they 'll say why 's it not it 's not working , and we always give out the same answer , so we thought , well , it 'd be nice to have a system that could sort of take care of this , and

speaker: Speaker_F
text: so , what I want to build is basically a a smart F A Q system .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: Now , what you

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh need to do here is you need to provide some context information which is more elaborate than "" I 'm looking for this and this and this keyword . "" So .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: And I think that I don't need to tell you this . I 'm I 'm sure you have the same when when somebody utters a sentence in a certain ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , context it , and and the same sentence in another context makes a huge difference . So ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: I want to be able to model information like , um , so in the in the context of in the context of developing distributed systems , of a at a computer science school , um ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: what kind of software is the person using , which homework assignment is he or she working on at the moment ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , maybe what 's the background of that student 's um , which um , which error message was encountered .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: So this sort of information I think should be transmitted , uh , when a certain document is retrieved .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: Now ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: basically giving this um Uh so we somehow need to have a formalized um , way of writing this down basically ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: and that 's where the shared interpretation of of certain terms and keywords comes in again .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: And ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: are written in Java . So some some inferences like that , now ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , u using this you can infer more information , and you could then match this to the meta - data of um off the documents you 're you 're searching against .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: given these inputs , and then I can compute how many documents match ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: and use this as a metric in the search .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh try to improve the quality of the search results , and I want to do this by having a depth uh , um , um steepest descent approach .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: So if I knew which operating system the person was working on , would this improve my search result ? And and having uh , uh a symbolic formalized model of this I could simply compute that ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: which questions are worth um , asking .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: And that 's what I then propagate back to the user , and and sort of try to optimize the search in this way .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: Now , the big

speaker: Speaker_F
text: problem that I 'm facing right now is um ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: it 's fairly easy to hack up a system uh quickly , that that works in the small domain , but the problem is obviously the scalability .

text: And uh uh , so Robert was mentioning uh , earlier today is that uh , Microsoft for example with their printer set up program has a Bayesian network ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: which does exactly this , but there you face a problem that these are very hard to extend .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: And so , uh what I 'm What I try to do is basically try to model this uh , in a way that you could really combine

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , knowledge from very different sources , and and um , sort of looking into some of the ideas that the semantic web community uh , came up with .

speaker: Speaker_F

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh , computational model . That that probably isn't expressive enough . So . So that 's another thing ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , which I think you 're also uh , uh looking into right now .

speaker: Speaker_F
text: um , uh , which uh , rules and which ontologies it it uses , or basically its view of the world ,

speaker: Speaker_F
text: uh you can get very different results . So it might ma make a lot of sense to actually query a lot of different search engines .

speaker: Speaker_F
